```{python, echo=FALSE}
import pandas as pd

# Read CSV
metrics = pd.read_csv(r"C:\UVI\Doug\Thesis project\ABSOLUTE_FINAL_DATA\website_metrics.csv")
metrics.columns = [col.replace("_", " ").title() for col in metrics.columns]

# Split into site dict
site_dfs = {site: df.drop(columns="Site").reset_index(drop=True)
            for site, df in metrics.groupby("Site")}

def make_site_table(site_name):
    df = site_dfs[site_name].copy()
    
    # Columns to round to 2 decimals
    round_2 = ["Overall Warming", "Min Temperature Increase", "Max Temperature Increase"]
    
    # Columns to round to 3 decimals
    round_3 = [c for c in df.select_dtypes(include="number").columns if c not in round_2]
    
    # Round and append °C to numeric columns (except seasonal months)
    for col in round_2:
        if col in df.columns:
            df[col] = df[col].round(2).astype(str) + " °C"
    for col in round_3:
        df[col] = df[col].round(3).astype(str) + " °C"
    
    # Pivot longer
    df_long = df.melt(var_name="Metric", value_name="Value")
    
    # Print clean Markdown table
    print(df_long.to_markdown(index=False))
```

# **Introduction**

Coral reefs are integral ecosystems, each with their own set of diverse and endemic organisms. The coral reefs of the Virgin Islands vary in size and depth extending down to the mesophotic range, aprroximately 30 to 150m. These shallow and mesophotic coral ecosystems (MCEs) are exposed to annual, seasonal, and dirunal variations in oceanographic variables (temperature, salinity, nutrients etc). This thesis will explore and characterize the oceanographic changes on the reefs, as well as investigate the effects from offshore internal waves.


## **Section 1 - Site Characterization**
There are several sites across the US Virgin Islands used in this study. These sites were chosen from those used in the Territorial Coral Reef Monitoring Project (TCRMP), with data coming from annual deployments of HOBO Pro V2 Water Temperature Loggers. Missing data gaps were filled using data from NPS deployments at the same site (Reference better).

![Map of sites: St. Thomas and St. John](C:/UVI/Doug/Thesis project/ABSOLUTE_FINAL_DATA/figure/STTSTJ.jpg)

## Black Point
Latitude: 18.3445  
Longitude: -64.98595  
Depth: 9 meters 
Years of Data: 2006, 2007, 2008, 2009, 2010, 2011, 2012, 2013, 2014, 2015, 2016, 2017, 2018, 2019, 2020, 2021, 2022, 2023, 2024

Characterization: Black Point is a shallow Orbicella-dominated reef located just offshore from the University of the Virgin Islands, St. Thomas. This site experiences strong seasonality, with temperatures steadily increasing overtime. The raise in minimum temperatures, in combination with low thermal relief from internal waves, exposes the site to reduced cooling and warmer "cold" months, likely making the site more susceptible to long term heat stress.


```{python, results = 'asis', echo=FALSE}
make_site_table("Black Point")
```

## Brewers Bay
Latitude: 18.34403  
Longitude: -64.98435  
Depth: 6 meters  
Years of Data: 2018, 2019, 2020, 2021, 2022, 2023, 2024

Characterization: Brewers Bay is a high cover orbicella annularis reef near UVI, with annual monitoring dating from 2018-2024. The dominant changes at this site are seasonality and annual temperature increase.

Temperature regressions show an overall increase of 1.22°C (0.203/yr) with max temperatures rising more than minimums at 1.25°C (0.208/yr) and 1.21°C (0.201/yr) respectively. This site experiences peak cold and warm seasons in February and September and shows peaks on semi-diurnal scales but is more influenced by annual changes. Internal waves do exhibit an effect on the reef, however it is very minor with and average temperature reduction of 0.10°C.

## Buck Island STT
Latitude: 18.27883  
Longitude: -64.89833  
Depth: 14 meters  
Years of Data: 2006, 2007, 2008, 2009, 2010, 2011, 2012, 2013, 2014, 2015, 2016, 2017, 2018, 2019, 2020, 2021, 2022, 2023, 2024


Characterization: Buck Island STT is a fringing reef near the uninhabited Buck Island, St. Thomas. Dominant shifts of the site occur through strong seasonality and annual temperature increase.
